You can also simulate a new column of data that has specified correlations to existing columns of data.

https://t.co/8O4ErYsauR https://t.co/SQ4UIPF3sS

Check your simulated data correlations, means, and SDs with check_sim_stats(df) 

(I'm working on making this table easier to read) https://t.co/w3gWvMGQuI

Parameters can be set per cell or constant using vectors or data frames (or matrices for r).

mu <- data.frame(
  cat = c(10, 12, 14, 16),
  dog = c(10, 15, 20, 25),
  row.names = within$time
)

df <- sim_design(
  within, between, 
  n = 100, mu = mu, sd = 5, r = .5
) https://t.co/yPGJR977i4

Set up factors and levels like this:

between <- list(
  pet = c(cat = "Cat Owners", dog = "Dog Owners")
)

within <- list(
  time = c("morning",  "noon",  "evening", "night")
)

If you're wondering what {faux} does, it helps you to simulate data for factorial designs quickly. This can be useful for things like teaching examples, testing code for preregistrations or registered reports, and simulation-based power analyses.

And I finally finished working on the functions I meant to. Now I can make the twitter card from a pkg logo with just this:

read_stim("pkgdown/logo.png") %>%
  to_size(social_media_size("twitter", "link")) %>%
  rename(new_names = "card") %>%
  write_stim("man/figures")

It's inspired by being frustrated that code chunks in Rmd files need "echo=TRUE" and not "echo=true", despite the later being totally unambiguous. So I want to be able to build into my own software the ability for users to guess a wide range of possibilities that will work.

Like if your user gives dimensions as a vector that might have names width/height, w/h, or just be in the order width, height.

dim <- c(h = 100, w = 200)
width <- xget(dim, "width", "w", 1)
height <- xget(dim, "height", "h", 2)

I meant to work on a package and ended up getting distracted writing a utility function again (that helps the function I meant to work on). This one is for if a user gives you a named vector or list and there are a few possibilities for the item you need.

https://t.co/IWEKIJBf7y

@cantabile You have to add another pb$tick(len=0) after the first sleep to get the 0% bar to display. This is useful if you have a process where each iteration takes a few seconds, so the user isn't sitting around wondering if it's working during the first iteration.

@cantabile I figured out a hack to add the following code right after you make the progress bar, before you start using it.

pb$tick(len=0)
Sys.sleep(0.5) 

The sleep time (on my computer) needs to be at least 140ms but is variable. It doesn't work if you sleep before the 0-len tick.

Does anyone use #rstats {progress} and have luck at making the bar display at 0% (or even the first tick)? I've added a thorough description of my problem to this unsolved question:

@RogertheGS @SimoneSchnall @improvingpsych @curatescience My perspective here is as a fierce proponent of team science. CS is mainly ELB now, but the commendation was given to a team that included other ECRs and senior academics. Is there another way to say ELB’s current actions aren’t in line with community value?

@RogertheGS @SimoneSchnall @improvingpsych @curatescience I think the difference for me is that this was a personal award. CS was a project award at a time when there were many working on the project. ELB seems to have gone off the rails (see his YT videos) and many still listed as project members are no longer involved.

@HeatherUrry @SimoneSchnall And looking at the SIPS awards page more closely, it would be useful to be clear about what the commendations are for and not just link to the whole project like an endorsement of all possible future activity.

@HeatherUrry @SimoneSchnall And I’m open to having my mind changed that it’s useful to treat minor awards like a pageant crown that can be revoked. I might feel different if it was a major personal award. And maybe signalling the society’s values can’t be done any other way?

@HeatherUrry @SimoneSchnall But I’d support a note on the awards page specifying that the award was for that specific aspect of the project at that time, and the CS org no longer operates in a way SIPS supports.

@HeatherUrry @SimoneSchnall And it’s my understanding that the commendations are for projects, not people. The CS project has done commendable things in the past, for which it rightly won an award praising those specific actions. The leader now has clear problems, it’s unclear how much others are involved.

@HeatherUrry @SimoneSchnall While this is an obvious case for a SIPs statement that CS’s current actions (and similar behaviour) aren’t in line with SIPS values, I’m not sure it’s useful for any society to constantly scrutinise past minor award winners for behaviour that isn’t consistent with their award.

I just have to keep reminding myself that ifelse() isn’t actually a convenient shortcut to if ... else, but meant specifically for vectorising.

@mickaelcanouil @rstats_tweets x = factor("A")
ifelse(TRUE, x, x) # returns integer
dplyr::if_else(TRUE, x, x) # returns factor

I also hardly ever use factors, but I'm handling user input to a function, so I won't have control over their preferences, and want to keep factors as factors in the output.

@mickaelcanouil @rstats_tweets Since I'm already in R...

dplyr::if_else(TRUE, x, NA)

Error: `false` must be a `factor` object, not a logical vector.

Both true and false arguments have to be compatible factors.

Context: I often need to turn a list of lists (that each describe a row) into a table, so I finally made a generic function. It might be useful to someone else (or someone will tell me there's already a better version of this ;)

#rstats frustration/lesson of the day:

ifelse() turns factors into integers

x = factor("A")

ifelse(TRUE, x, NA) # returns 1 (int)

if (TRUE) { x } else { NA } # returns A (factor)

Code  for this:

read_stim(imgdir) %>% 
  auto_delineate() %>%
  align(procrustes = TRUE) %>%
  crop_pad(250, 50, 50, 50) %>%
  resize(height = 300) %>%
  crop(height = 1.2, y_off = -.2, fill = "black") %>%
  label(c("15cm", "30cm", "45cm", "60cm"), "white", 3) %>%
  animate()

TIL that you can get a list of possible aesthetics (that are just ... in the help files) for a geom in #rstats #ggplot2 with the following code:

geom <- "violin" # or whatever geom you want
ggplot2:::check_subclass(geom, "Geom")$aesthetics()

@bmwiernik Same problem :( but pretty!

```{r, fig.width = 10, fig.height = 11/2}
ggplot() + ggplot() +
  grid::textGrob('Label 1') + grid::textGrob('Label 2') +
  patchwork::plot_layout(ncol = 2, heights = c(10, 1))

ggsave("test/demo.png", width = 10, height = 11/2)
```

I spent most of today wrestling with #rstats httr and am posting this for anyone else who might be wondering how to send data to a PHP script so it's available as an array in $_POST['x']

x = as.list(LETTERS)
names(x) = rep('x[]', length(x))
httr::POST(url, x)

@IceVisLab For undergraduate *studies*, definitely R! SPSS just isn't suitable for the data processing part of a real study. It's OK for canned data that are already in the exact format you want to analyse, but that's seldom the case. And the visualisation in R is so much better.

@zerdeve This is a really good idea, although I’m not aware of many awards that come with money, so the resources are mainly time. But how to get rid of the Red Queen situation where not giving awards puts people in your field at a competitive disadvantage for jobs, tenure and promotion?

@psforscher @thuyvytnguyen You can’t evaluate the benefit without knowing the cost. And even if the cost was literally 0, it will be important to look at heterogeneity. Does the intervention improve 1% and not affect 99%, or help slightly more people than it hurts?
